basics.name: Jamie McGowan
basics.label: Research Scientist
basics.summary: I am a Research Scientist in AI focussed on exploring topics in foundational AI. My research interests include topics surrounding optimisation, meta-learning, structured intelligence and challenges in representation learning. In addition, my research involves developing real-world applications of AI to solve engineering problems.

work.name: UCL Centre for Data Intensive Science and Industry
work.summary: I received a funded fellowship position to work collaboratively with the Machine Learning team at ASOS building a system to predict customer returns using Graph Neural Networks. My responsibilities involved leading a small group of PhD students and MSc students who worked with me during this time.

work.name: University College London
work.summary: My research involved computational modelling of a variety of unknown higher order functions in perturbation theory, describing quantum interactions within particle collisions. Subsequently, I developed a framework for fitting this approximate theory to datasets via Hessian methods to gain a handle on the theoretical uncertainties present in physical quantities calculated in quantum field theory.

work.name: MediaTek Research
work.summary: During this time, I worked on a Meta-Learning project based on an adaptation of the MAML algorithm for hierarchical learning. Our new algorithm, TreeMAML, achieved superior performance compared to similar meta-learning algorithms on NLP tasks by exploiting prior knowledge of the language tree.

work.name: MediaTek Research
work.summary: During this time, I worked on a Meta-Learning project based on an adaptation of the MAML algorithm for hierarchical learning. Our new algorithm, TreeMAML, achieved superior performance compared to similar meta-learning algorithms on NLP tasks by exploiting prior knowledge of the language tree.

projects.name: The Alan Turing Institute
projects.summary: Intensive hackathon working with ML techniques to produce a podcast recommendation algorithm for a company named Entale.

projects.name: UK Atomic Energy Authority (UKAEA)
projects.summary: Proof of concept project to show that the calibration of images from 'shaky' cameras inside a fusion reactor could be automated using off-the-shelf CNN models.

projects.name: Unification of the Standard Model
projects.summary: Explored various 	extbf{unification group} candidates including $SU(5)$, $SO(10)$ and $E_{6}$ with and without supersymmetry.

awards.title: High Energy Physics PhD Thesis Prize

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).
